pullRequest.body:
This file describes the transformation of the fderiv to gradient for functions from H to ‚Ñù, where H is a Hilbert (complete inner product) space. This is a substitution for the previous pull request #7011.

---
<!-- The text above the `---` will become the commit message when your
PR is merged. Please leave a blank newline before the `---`, otherwise
GitHub will format the text above it as a title.

To indicate co-authors, include lines at the bottom of the commit message
(that is, before the `---`) using the following format:

Co-authored-by: Author Name <author@email.com>

Any other comments you want to keep out of the PR commit should go
below the `---`, and placed outside this HTML comment, or else they
will be invisible to reviewers.

If this PR depends on other PRs, please list them below this comment,
using the following format:
- [ ] depends on: #abc [optional extra text]
- [ ] depends on: #xyz [optional extra text]
-->

[![Open in Gitpod](https://gitpod.io/button/open-in-gitpod.svg)](https://gitpod.io/from-referrer/)

nodes.body: Sorry for the mistake, this is the substitution for #7073.

Hi @chenyili0818, thanks for your contribution.  I'm going to ask you to start a discussion topic on Zulip (in the "mathlib4" or "PR reviews" channel) about your reasons for wanting a definition of gradient in this form -- is it really too awkward to work with the Frechet derivative in your intended use case?  If we add this definition to mathlib, we will need to duplicate a lot of the theory of the Frechet derivative (as you have already done in this PR), so it's a lot of overhead and we should be sure that it's worth while.

Here, I will make a first review of the PR assuming that after the discussion everyone agrees that having this definition is worth while.

Hello, thanks for reviewer's reply. We have create [a zulip chat to discuss the introduction of `Gradient` in Mathlib.](https://leanprover.zulipchat.com/#narrow/stream/287929-mathlib4/topic/define.20gradient.20of.20scalar-valued.20function.20on.20a.20Hilbert/near/390212910). Also we will address the problems above.

We rewrite our defitions about HasGradientAtFilter, HasGradientWithinAt and HasGradientAt according to fderiv. We also add some basic calculation properties about add, minus, negative, compose, mul.  Any suggestions are welcome. The necessity of this defition is discussed on zulip https://leanprover.zulipchat.com/#narrow/stream/287929-mathlib4/topic/define.20gradient.20of.20scalar-valued.20function.20on.20a.20Hilbert.20space/near/390214016

When you have dealt with a comment, can you click on "Resolve conversation", so that what remains to be done is easier to follow? Don't resolve the conversation only if you expect that the conversation on this specific point will continue.
Thank you for your crucial advice. I modify the first file Basic.lean and delete the second file Calculation.lean. Later I will open another PR to discuss about it. Hope we can soon merge the PR.
I don't know what has happened with the merge commit, but now a lot of indentation is wrong. You can see it by going to the `Files changed` tab and looking at the linter complaints.
Very sorry for my personal mistake, I push the wrong version of my file. So there may be some misleading.
Thank you very much for your advice

bors r+
Thanks, and congrats for your first PR!

Can you merge master and fix the build?
Sorry but it seems that I don't know what to do now and can you please teach me more detailed information about solving this problem. Thank you again for your help to this PR!

Assuming you are on your branch and that VsCode is closed, issue the following commands in a terminal:
```
git pull
git merge origin/master
lake exe cache get
lake build
```
I expect the build step will show some failure in the file on gradients. Fix the build, commit your changes and push back to the server.
I think I have fixed the problem.
Hello, can you help me to merge this PR? Thank you!
I committed some missed APIs, style changes, and golfs. feel free to revert if you don't want these changes.
If you are happy with everything, you just need to reply "bors merge" to this message, and that should be it!

I have given a style review on the beginning of the first file. It would probably speed up the review process if you cut the PR in two, with only the first file in the first PR (but of course all the style comments apply to all files!). Don't worry, it's completely normal that your first PR takes some time to get ironed out.
I have only looked at the first file. It's beginning to look very good, thanks! Could you remove the second file from the PR, and then hopefully we can get the PR in quickly?
It's almost perfect, thanks!

Rename to use projection notation: `HasGradientAt.hasFDerivAt`.  Similar throughout.  (If you are new to Lean, you may need to study how projection notation works.)

```suggestion
theorem toDual.unique {f‚ÇÅ g‚ÇÅ : E} (h : (‚àá* f‚ÇÅ) = (‚àá* g‚ÇÅ)) : f‚ÇÅ = g‚ÇÅ := by
```

```

```

```suggestion

```

```suggestion
theorem HasGradnAt.continuousAt (hf : HasGradnAt f gradf x) : ContinuousAt f x := by
```
No affiliations
Not needed, this is `deriv`

```suggestion
  ((toDual ‚Ñù E).apply_symm_apply gradient').symm
```
We abbreviate only when the the full-length wording is very long.  Here, it's not so long, so I would write in full: `gradient`.  Same for `HasGradientAt`.

```suggestion
  rw [HasGradnAt] at h
  convert h
  exact ((toDual ‚Ñù E).apply_symm_apply gradient').symm
```

These should all follow immediately from the corresponding proofs for `HasFDerivAt`.  Example:
```suggestion
  rw [HasGradnAt] at hf ‚ä¢
  convert hf.const_smul c
  simp
```
Make these exact copies of similar results for `HasFDerivAt` (and use filter notation), and prove them directly from those results.

In mathlib we state these kinds of result using filters, not `Œµ - Œ¥`.  In principle you could do this here, but I think it's better just to delete them all, because (as you will see from my review below) every result you prove about `HasGradnAt` is an immediate consequence of the corresponding result about `HasFDerivAt`, without needing to unfold definitions further.

`toDual ùïú F` is an equiv, so it is injective and sujective by general properties: the proof of the theorem should be a one-liner but, more importantly, you shouldn't need the theorem at all!
Thank you for your advice. We totally agree that there is no need to have this theorem. So we update our proof.

```suggestion
Let `f` be a function from a Hilbert Space `F` to `ùïú` (`ùïú` is `‚Ñù` or `‚ÑÇ`) , `x` be a point in `F`
```

```suggestion
and `f'` be a vector in F. Then
```

```suggestion
  `f x' = f x + ‚ü®f', x' - x‚ü© + o (x' - x)` when `x'` converges along the filter `L`.-/
```

```suggestion
def gradient (f : F ‚Üí ùïú) (x : F) : F := (toDual ùïú F).symm (fderiv ùïú f x)
```
We have complicated naming conventions. Long story short, it should be a lowercase `gradient` here.

```suggestion
  HasGradientWithinAt f f' s x ‚Üî HasFDerivWithinAt f (toDual ùïú F f') s x := Iff.rfl
```

This theorem should rather read: if `HasFDerivWithinAt f u s x` then `HasGradientWithinAt f ((toDual ùïú F).symm u) s x`. And maybe add the iff version also.
Edit: I see that the iff version is below. Then I would just drop the current lemma (which is quite unnatural, if needed one can resort to the iff version) and only keep the natural version. And probably move the other versions very close to here, as they have exactly the same flavor.
same thing as above.

the second and next lines in theorem statements should be indented by 4 spaces. But here you should just remove this theorem: it is just a particular case of `LinearIsometryEquiv.apply_symm_apply` (as you can find by trying `exact?` to see if your theorem can be proved directly).

This is the definition of `toDual`, so probably it already exists (and probably it is given very close to the definition). Can you find it? If so, you should remove your statement. If not, you should move it just after the definition of `toDual`.

All these lemmas are not specifically about gradients, and should be moved to the right place if you really need them (the first two are probably not useful as they can just be proved by simp).

```suggestion
theorem HasGradientAt.hasDerivAt' {g : ‚Ñù ‚Üí ‚Ñù} {g' u : ‚Ñù} (h : HasGradientAt g g' u) :
```
Same thing below.
You shouldn't need to distinguish between the two cases, as `gradient` has been defined precisely so that the equality holds.

Thank you for your advice. I think we have the need to distinguish whether it is differentiable or not here. The same as the defition of deriv or fderiv, the definition of gradient does not contain the differentiablity. For the convience of prove, I think it is intuitive to think consider the cases.
Can you open a section here, named `OneDimension` or something like that?
I don't think you have opened the section at the right place. It should probably be before the `variable` line, as all theorems talking about `g` will be one-dimensional theorems.

The docstring does not really match the statement, as it doesn't talk about gradients.

Do you really need this lemma? Otherwise, I would just drop it as it is pretty specific and was introduced for the derivative only as a device to prove another result.

Thank you for your advice! It seems that this theorem actually should not belong to this file. We think it is useful, but it just need not to place here. So we decide to delete it here and add at the place where we need the theorem.
It doesn't look like it has been deleted.

**[lint-style]** reported by [reviewdog](https://github.com/reviewdog/reviewdog) :dog:
```suggestion mul_one] at h; exact h ```
The conversation is marked as resolved, but if I see correctly the space is still missing. Let me unresolve it.

```suggestion

theorem Gradient_zero_of_not_differentiableAt (h : ¬¨DifferentiableAt ùïú f x) : ‚àá f x = 0 := by
```
Empty line between theorems.

```suggestion
    gradf = gradg :=
  (toDual ùïú F).injective
    ((HasGradientAt_iff_HasFDerivAt.mp hf).unique (HasGradientAt_iff_HasFDerivAt.mp hg))
```
If the proof does not fit on one line, don't put anything (except `by`) on the same line as `:=`.
These statements don't mention the gradient. Could you move them to a more suitable file?

```suggestion
    (fun h => f (x + h) - f x - ‚ü™f' , h‚ü´) =o[ùìù 0] fun h => h :=
  hasFDerivAt_iff_isLittleO_nhds_zero
```
If you can avoid breaking meaningful formulas in the middle, it's much better.

```suggestion
    ContinuousOn f s := fun x hx => (hderiv x hx).continuousAt.continuousWithinAt
```

```suggestion
    ContinuousWithinAt f s x := HasGradientAtFilter.tendsto_nhds inf_le_left h
```

pullRequest.title: [Merged by Bors] - feat: define gradient of scalar-valued function on a Hilbert space

nodes.body: Sorry for the mistake, this is the substitution for #7073.

Hi @chenyili0818, thanks for your contribution.  I'm going to ask you to start a discussion topic on Zulip (in the "mathlib4" or "PR reviews" channel) about your reasons for wanting a definition of gradient in this form -- is it really too awkward to work with the Frechet derivative in your intended use case?  If we add this definition to mathlib, we will need to duplicate a lot of the theory of the Frechet derivative (as you have already done in this PR), so it's a lot of overhead and we should be sure that it's worth while.

Here, I will make a first review of the PR assuming that after the discussion everyone agrees that having this definition is worth while.

Hello, thanks for reviewer's reply. We have create [a zulip chat to discuss the introduction of `Gradient` in Mathlib.](https://leanprover.zulipchat.com/#narrow/stream/287929-mathlib4/topic/define.20gradient.20of.20scalar-valued.20function.20on.20a.20Hilbert/near/390212910). Also we will address the problems above.

Remaining comments which cannot be posted as a review comment to avoid GitHub Rate Limit

<details>
<summary>lint-style</summary>

[Mathlib/Analysis/Calculus/Gradient/Calculus.lean|339|](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/blob/270d028872205181511eef556c362d1ab964aa3e/Mathlib/Analysis/Calculus/Gradient/Calculus.lean#L339) 
[Mathlib/Analysis/Calculus/Gradient/Calculus.lean|349|](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/blob/270d028872205181511eef556c362d1ab964aa3e/Mathlib/Analysis/Calculus/Gradient/Calculus.lean#L349)

[Mathlib/Analysis/Calculus/Gradient/Calculus.lean|374|](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/blob/270d028872205181511eef556c362d1ab964aa3e/Mathlib/Analysis/Calculus/Gradient/Calculus.lean#L374) 
[Mathlib/Analysis/Calculus/Gradient/Calculus.lean|378|](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/blob/270d028872205181511eef556c362d1ab964aa3e/Mathlib/Analysis/Calculus/Gradient/Calculus.lean#L378) 
[Mathlib/Analysis/Calculus/Gradient/Calculus.lean|382|](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/blob/270d028872205181511eef556c362d1ab964aa3e/Mathlib/Analysis/Calculus/Gradient/Calculus.lean#L382) 
[Mathlib/Analysis/Calculus/Gradient/Calculus.lean|390|](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/blob/270d028872205181511eef556c362d1ab964aa3e/Mathlib/Analysis/Calculus/Gradient/Calculus.lean#L390) 
[Mathlib/Analysis/Calculus/Gradient/Calculus.lean|395|](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/blob/270d028872205181511eef556c362d1ab964aa3e/Mathlib/Analysis/Calculus/Gradient/Calculus.lean#L395) 
</details>

We rewrite our defitions about HasGradientAtFilter, HasGradientWithinAt and HasGradientAt according to fderiv. We also add some basic calculation properties about add, minus, negative, compose, mul.  Any suggestions are welcome. The necessity of this defition is discussed on zulip https://leanprover.zulipchat.com/#narrow/stream/287929-mathlib4/topic/define.20gradient.20of.20scalar-valued.20function.20on.20a.20Hilbert.20space/near/390214016

When you have dealt with a comment, can you click on "Resolve conversation", so that what remains to be done is easier to follow? Don't resolve the conversation only if you expect that the conversation on this specific point will continue.

I have given a style review on the beginning of the first file. It would probably speed up the review process if you cut the PR in two, with only the first file in the first PR (but of course all the style comments apply to all files!). Don't worry, it's completely normal that your first PR takes some time to get ironed out.
I have only looked at the first file. It's beginning to look very good, thanks! Could you remove the second file from the PR, and then hopefully we can get the PR in quickly?
Thank you for your crucial advice. I modify the first file Basic.lean and delete the second file Calculation.lean. Later I will open another PR to discuss about it. Hope we can soon merge the PR.
I don't know what has happened with the merge commit, but now a lot of indentation is wrong. You can see it by going to the `Files changed` tab and looking at the linter complaints.
Very sorry for my personal mistake, I push the wrong version of my file. So there may be some misleading.
It's almost perfect, thanks!
Thank you very much for your advice

bors r+
Thanks, and congrats for your first PR!

Build failed (retrying...):
  * Build
Sorry I may wonder how to fix this fail, thank you!
bors r-
Canceled.
Can you merge master and fix the build?
Sorry but it seems that I don't know what to do now and can you please teach me more detailed information about solving this problem. Thank you again for your help to this PR!

Assuming you are on your branch and that VsCode is closed, issue the following commands in a terminal:
```
git pull
git merge origin/master
lake exe cache get
lake build
```
I expect the build step will show some failure in the file on gradients. Fix the build, commit your changes and push back to the server.
I think I have fixed the problem.
Hello, can you help me to merge this PR? Thank you!
I committed some missed APIs, style changes, and golfs. feel free to revert if you don't want these changes.
If you are happy with everything, you just need to reply "bors merge" to this message, and that should be it!
